titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Nancy Spero Papers, 1940s-2009, in the Archives of American Art AAA.spernanc
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Catherine S. Gaines

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-02-19T14:27-0500

did.abstract: The papers of painter, collage artist, and printmaker Nancy Spero measure 26.9 linear feet and are dated 1940s-2009. Biographical materials, correspondence, interviews, writings, subject files, personal business records, printed material, and photographic materials provide an overview of her exhibitions, major projects, and personal life. Also documented is her interest and participation in political movements and social issues including anti-war, women's rights, animal rights, repressive regimes, and the treatment of political prisoners.
did.langmaterial: The majority of the collection is in English, with some material in Dutch, Chinese, German, Italian, Japanese, and Spanish.
English; Dutch; Chinese, German; Italian,Japanese; Spanish

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original material requires an appointment. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Nancy Spero papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Nancy Spero papers, 1940s-2009. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: This collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared in 2014 by Catherine S. Gaines. The Archives of American Art has implemented minimal processing tactics when possible in order to increase access to more of our collections.

Minimal processing included arrangement to the series and folder levels. Generally, items within folders were simply verified with folder titles, but not arranged further. The collection was rehoused in archival containers and folders, but not all staples and clips were removed.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of Nancy Spero in 1979. The majority of the collection was donated by her sons, Stephen Golub, Philip Golub, and Paul Golub in 2013.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in 9 series:

list.item: Series 5: Subject Files, circa 1950-2009 (Boxes 6-18, 29, RD 30; 12.6 linear feet)
Series 6: Personal Business Records, circa 1976-2008 (Boxes 18-19; 1 linear foot)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of painter, printmaker, and collage artist Nancy Spero measure 26.9 linear feet and are dated 1940s-2009. Biographical materials, correspondence, interviews,writings, subject files, personal business records, printed material, and photographic materials provide an overview of her exhibitions, major projects, and personal life. Also documented is her interest and participation in political and social movements including anti-war, women's rights, animal rights, and raising awareness about repressive regimes, and the treatment of political prisoners.

Biographical materials include 29 audiovisual recordings about Nancy Spero and her work. Also found are biographical notes, resumes, and her passport. Correspondence concerns exhibitions, projects, travel, general news of family and friends, social events, and fundraising for political and social causes that Spero supported.

Interviews with Spero, conducted for a variety of purposes, include 7 audiovisual recordings, many transcripts, and published versions. Also, there are several joint interviews with Nancy Spero and Leon Golub. Spero's writings consist of notes, artist's statements, and articles. Also included are 7 audiovisual recordings of talks by Spero and her participation in panel discussions.

Subject files document many of Spero's personal and professional projects, relationships, and interests. Especially well documented is A.I.R. Gallery which includes 42 sound cassettes of talks presented in its "Current Issues and Events" series (1982-1984), gallery correspondence, exhibition documentation, and records of the A.I.R. Partnership.

Personal business records include many inventories and lists. Also documented are gifts, loans, sales, prices, reproduction permissions and fees. Printed material consists of a variety of items such as books, clippings, exhibition catalogs and announcements, periodicals, press releases and reproductions. Many items mention Spero and/or include reproductions of her work. Also found with printed material are 22 commercially produced audiovisual recordings about various subjects.

Photographic materials include photographs, digital images, slides, negatives and color transparencies of artwork, exhibition installations, and people. Artwork is mainly by Spero and exhibition installations record some of her solo shows. Images of people include Nancy Spero, Leon Golub, unidentified friends and family members.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Nancy Spero (1926-2009) was a figurative painter, printmaker, and collage artist in New York City whose multi-media work often incorporated text. She was an ardent feminist and activist whose political and social concerns were expressed in her art.

Born in Cleveland, Nancy Spero lived in Chicago from the time she was a very young child until completing her studies at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (BFA 1949) where she met her future husband, painter Leon Golub (1922-2004). She studied briefly in Paris and lived in New York City, returning to Chicago after her marriage in 1951. The couple and their two sons lived in Italy from 1956 to 1957. In 1959, after a few years in New York, the family moved to Paris where Spero developed an interest in existentialism and produced a series of black paintings. When Spero and Golub returned to New York in 1964, their family consisted of three sons.

Nancy Spero was strongly affected by the war in Vietnam and the many social changes of the period. She became a social activist and feminist, joined various organizations, and participated in a variety of demonstrations. Work such as the War series began to include political and sexual imagery. Spero was among the founding members of the women's cooperative A.I.R. Gallery established in 1972. In 1974 she decided to make women in mythology, history, art, and literature the exclusive subject of her work. Included in this vein are major series and installations, among them Torture of Women, Notes in Time on Women, The First Language, and her 66th Street/Lincoln Center subway station mosaic mural Artemis, Acrobats, Divas and Dancers.

Spero exhibited in the 1950 Salon des Independents and her first solo exhibition (in tandem with Leon Golub) was held at Indiana University in 1958. Thereafter, she showed sporadically until nearly 30 years later when her career flourished and she enjoyed international stature. Beginning in 1986, each year brought multiple solo exhibitions at galleries and museums in the United States and internationally. In addition, she continued to participate in group shows such as "Documenta" and the Venice Biennale. Her work is included in the permanent collections of museums throughout the world.

Awards and honors included the Skowhegan Medal for Works on Paper (1995), Hiroshima Art Prize shared with Leon Golub (1996), The Women's Caucus for Art award for Outstanding Achievement in Visual Arts (2003), and The Women's Caucus for Art Distinguished Artist Award for Lifetime Achievement (2005). Spero was awarded honorary Doctorates of Fine Arts by The School of the Art Institute of Chicago (1991) and Williams College (2001), and was elected a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters (2006).
After several years of declining health, Nancy Spero died from heart failure in New York City, October 18, 2009.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Also among the holdings of the Archives of American Art an interview of Nancy Spero conducted 2008 Februay 6-July 24, by Judith Olch Richards, and the papers of Spero's husband, Leon Golub.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes 1 motion picture film and 28 audiovisual recordings (1 U-matic, 21 VHS, 5 DVD, and 1 Hi8) about Nancy Spero and her work. One passport for the period 1996-2006 is a photocopy.

did.physdesc: Includes 1 film reel: 8mm; 1 videocassette (U-matic); 1 videocassette (Hi8); 21 videocassettes (VHS); 5 video discs (DVD)

did.unittitle: Membership Card, Passports, and International Certificates of Vaccination

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Professional correspondence is with museums, art dealers, artists' organizations, groups representing many political and social issues of interest to Spero, and others. Topics include exhibitions, projects, publications, travel, and fundraising. Personal correspondence with family and friends includes general news, invitations to a variety of social events, greeting cards, and drawings by grandchildren.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged by year. The majority of Spero's professional correspondence is scattered among subject files (Series 5) and a few letters from authors are attached to manuscripts about Spero and her work (Series 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interviews were conducted by curators, art historians, students, and writers for exhibition research, articles, student papers, and other purposes. Included are 7 videocassettes (VHS), transcripts, and published versions. Most of the transcripts are edited versions; in some cases, there are multiple versions. Many were published, sometimes years after the interview. Also, there are several joint interviews with Nancy Spero and Leon Golub.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Transcripts are arranged by interview date and published versions by date of publication. Additional interviews are found among the subject files (Series 5) and with printed material (Series 7).

did.unittitle: Nancy Spero and Leon Golub Interviews (Transcripts)
Nancy Spero and Leon Golub Interviews, Published Versions (Transcripts)
Nancy Spero and Leon Golub Interview

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writings by Spero include a variety of notes and artist's statements. Talks and panel discussions are documented by notes, texts, and 5 videocassettes (VHS). There are published versions of articles about the Whitney Museum's treatment of women artists, pursuing her career while raising a family, and other topics. In addition, there are published versions of forewords to a small book about Cesarini Sforza and the catalog of an exhibition for which she was the sole juror. Writings by other authors are about Spero and miscellaneous subjects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Spero's writings are arranged by format. Those by others are alphabetized by author. Additional writings by Spero and others are found among the subject files (Series 5).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subject files are comprised of correspondence, writings, printed items, photographs, and audiovisual materials in varying combinations. Audiovisual recordings consist of 42 sound cassettes, 1 sound disc (CD), 5 video discs (DVD), 30 videocassettes (VHS), and 4 computer discs (3.5"). The files document Spero's professional and personal projects, activities, relationships, and interests. Among the most extensively documented subjects are: A.I.R. Gallery, animals, Baltic Center for Contemporary Art exhibition, Barbara Gross Galerie, benefits, Centro Galego de Arte Contemporanea exhibition, Christine König Galerie, Codex Artaud, Hiroshima City Museum of Contemporary Art, Josh Baer Gallery, Kunsthalle zu Kiel, Metropolitan Transit Authority Project for 66th Street/Lincoln Center Subway Station ( Artemis, Acrobats, Divas and Dancers), Museu d'Art Contemporani de Barcelona traveling exhibition, Museum of Fine Arts Boston banners, Venice Biennale 52 (2007), and women. Other files of note are: Jon Bird, Clayton Eshelman, Deborah Frizzell, Paul Golub, Philip Golub, Stephen Golub, Ana Mendieta, Rick [Ulrich] and Harriet Meyer, Museum of Modern Art Notes in Time gift of Ulrich Meyer, Hans-Ulrich Obrist, and Rip Off File.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is alphabetized by folder title. Filing is inconsistent; for example, subject files concerning exhibitions and loans may be filed by exhibition title, museum or gallery, and sometimes by city or country. Correspondence (Series 2) may include individuals, institutions, exhibitions and events represented by subject files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Personal business records include many inventories of Spero's artwork including some for specific media. Also found are inventories of the Leon Golub Marital Trust and paintings by Golub. The gift record (photocopy) notes "Copy by Leon of Nancy's Gift Record* - Original lost in the 71st Street fire 1972-1973, *1969 to 1971-1972 is missing." Also found are records concerning reproduction permissions and fees, appraisals, consignments, and loans.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by record type, and filed alphabetically by folder title.

did.unittitle: Appraisal of Artwork by Spero, Insurance Values
Portfolios, Argon and Lists of Extra Prints and Missing Prints
Prints, Lithographs, Earlier and Smaller Editions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed materials consist of a wide variety of items including books, clippings, exhibition catalogs and announcements, periodicals, press releases, and reproductions. A high percentage are about Spero and/or reproduce her work. Some clippings and periodicals of a more general nature mention artists, exhibitions, social issues, and political movements of interest to Spero. This series includes a number of commercialy produced recordings: Tellis the Audio Cassette Magazine, #5 & # 6 Special Double Audio Visual Issue (1 sound cassette and pamphlet), as well as 20 videocassettes (VHS) and 2 sound discs (CD) about various subjects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Printed material is arranged by format and filed alphabetically by folder title. Exhibition catalogs, announcements and invitations have been sorted into the categories of Spero solo exhibitions, Spero group exhibitions, and other artists. Additional printed material is found with biographical materials (Series 1) and attached to correspondence (Series 2). Interviews with Nancy Spero and her published writings by her are filed with interviews and writings (Series 3 and Series 4, respectively). A wide variety of printed items are found in many subject files (Series 5),

did.unittitle: Conference, Symposium, and Panel Discussion Announcements and Programs
Exhibition Announcements and Invitations - Spero Solo Exhibitions
Exhibition Announcements and Invitations - Spero Solo Exhibitions
Exhibition Announcements and Invitations - Spero Group Exhibitions
Exhibition Announcements and Invitations - Other Artists
Periodicals with Reproductions of Spero's Work
Publication Announcements - Book, Print Portfolio, and Miscellaneous

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographs and color digital prints; also found are slides, some negatives, and color transparencies. Images of artwork are mostly by Spero. Photographs of artwork by others include many unsigned works as well as pieces by Traude Linhardt, Mira Schor, and Ana Mendieta. Views of exhibition installations record Nancy Spero's solo exhibitions and her participation in the 2007 "Venice Biennale, 52." People appearing in photographs are Nancy Spero, Leon Golub, their sons, grandchildren, Nancy's sister Carol Newman, and unidentified people, most likely friends. Folders titled "family" and "friends" include views in which Spero and/or Golub are present. Miscellaneous subjects are a dog and owl. One photograph album, circa 2000s, consists of pictures that appear to have been taken on the same day; included are views of Nancy Spero with friends and family.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Photographic materials are arranged by subject.

unittitle.emph: Notes in Time on Women, Part II

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of 18 videocassettes (VHS). Many include no identifying information while others are too vaguely labeled to determine the series with which they belong.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Additional audiovisual materials can be found among the biographical materials (Series 1), interviews (Series 3), writings (Series 4), and subject files (Series 5).
